verses.text: Then Jesus was led up by the Spirit into the wilderness to be tempted by the devil.
verses.comment: Jesus is shown acting in obedience to the Spirit and facing temptation, prefiguring the trials of Israel in the desert (cf. Exodus 34:28). This reinforces His identification with mankind and the fulfillment of Old Testament patterns.

verses.text: He fasted forty days and forty nights, and afterward He was hungry.
verses.comment: The forty days recalls Moses and Elijah's fasts, tying Jesus' mission to the Old Testament and highlighting Him as the new lawgiver and prophet.

verses.text: And the tempter came to Him and said, 'If you are the Son of God, command these stones to become bread.'
verses.comment: Calling Jesus 'Son of God' indicates a claim to divinity. The temptation repeats Israel’s testing in the wilderness, but Jesus stands firm where Israel failed.

verses.text: But He answered, 'It is written, "Man shall not live by bread alone, but by every word that comes from the mouth of God."'
verses.comment: Jesus quotes Deuteronomy, affirming the authority of Scripture and spiritual nourishment. His obedience contrasts with Adam and Israel, fulfilling in Himself what they lacked.

verses.text: Then the devil took Him into the holy city and set Him on the pinnacle of the temple,
verses.comment: Jerusalem, the holy city, represents the center of worship. The temple's pinnacle signifies religious authority, hinting at Jesus' higher spiritual authority.

verses.text: and said to Him, 'If you are the Son of God, throw yourself down; for it is written, "He will command His angels concerning you," and, "On their hands they will bear you up, lest you strike your foot against a stone."'
verses.comment: The devil quotes Scripture, showing that even truth can be misused. Jesus resists, modeling discernment and humility, traits essential for all who seek to follow Him.

verses.text: Jesus said to him, 'Again it is written, "You shall not test the Lord your God."'
verses.comment: Jesus identifies Himself as the Lord God, reiterating His divinity. He upholds Scriptural authority, yet shows its proper use within faith and trust.

verses.text: Again, the devil took Him to a very high mountain, and showed Him all the kingdoms of the world and their glory.
verses.comment: Temptation concerns earthly power, but Christ's kingdom is not of this world. The high mountain echoes prophetic visions of the Messiah’s reign over all nations.

verses.text: And he said to Him, 'All these things I will give You, if You will fall down and worship me.'
verses.comment: Satan seeks to usurp worship that belongs to God alone, highlighting the spiritual battle over true worship. Jesus resists, staying loyal to the Father.

verses.text: Then Jesus said to him, 'Away with you, Satan! For it is written, "You shall worship the Lord your God, and serve Him only."'
verses.comment: Jesus’ command reveals His divine authority over evil, establishing the exclusive worship due to God. This affirms not only a high christology but the necessity of true worship.

verses.text: Then the devil left Him, and behold, angels came and ministered to Him.
verses.comment: Heavenly beings serve Jesus, subtly revealing His divine status. The pattern of suffering before glory is a key biblical theme.

verses.text: Now when Jesus heard that John had been arrested, He withdrew into Galilee.
verses.comment: Jesus’ public ministry begins as John’s ends, revealing a transition from prophet to Messiah. Fulfillment of prophecy continues.

verses.text: Leaving Nazareth, He went and lived in Capernaum by the sea, in the territory of Zebulun and Naphtali,
verses.comment: The move to Capernaum fulfills prophecy and signals the light dawning in Galilee, as in Isaiah’s vision of salvation reaching the nations.

verses.text: so that what was spoken by the prophet Isaiah might be fulfilled:
verses.comment: Matthew often points out the Old Testament's fulfillment in Jesus, showing a continuity of God’s plan through history.

verses.text: "Land of Zebulun and land of Naphtali, by the way of the sea, beyond the Jordan, Galilee of the Gentiles—"
verses.comment: This quotation places Jesus in the context of God's promise to bring light to those in spiritual darkness, prefiguring the Church's mission to all peoples.

verses.text: "the people dwelling in darkness have seen a great light, and for those dwelling in the region and shadow of death, a light has dawned."
verses.comment: Jesus fulfills the prophecy as the true light, echoing imagery later used of the Church’s role in guiding all humanity from darkness to truth.

verses.text: From that time on Jesus began to preach, saying, 'Repent, for the kingdom of heaven is at hand.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ proclamation echoes John the Baptist, but He brings its fulfillment. The message of repentance and the kingdom remains central to the faith, and is proclaimed through tradition, word, and sacrament.

verses.text: As He was walking by the Sea of Galilee, He saw two brothers, Simon called Peter and Andrew his brother, casting a net into the sea, for they were fishermen.
verses.comment: The call of Peter and Andrew highlights Christ selecting ordinary men for extraordinary missions. Peter will later be foundational as the chief among the apostles.

verses.text: And He said to them, 'Follow Me, and I will make you fishers of men.'
verses.comment: Jesus issues a direct call, conferring a mission of evangelization and spiritual authority—a continuation of divine calling found throughout Scripture.

verses.text: Immediately they left their nets and followed Him.
verses.comment: The disciples’ total response models complete trust and obedience, themes important for authentic discipleship and apostolic succession.

verses.text: Going on from there, He saw two other brothers, James the son of Zebedee, and John his brother, in the boat with Zebedee their father, mending their nets. He called them,
verses.comment: Jesus’ personal call demonstrates His initiative in establishing a new community of faith, prefiguring the communal nature of worship and leadership.

verses.text: and immediately they left the boat and their father and followed Him.
verses.comment: Their response underscores the primacy of Jesus’ call over all earthly ties, pointing toward the supremacy of Christ’s mission for every follower.

verses.text: And He went throughout all Galilee, teaching in their synagogues and proclaiming the gospel of the kingdom, and healing every disease and every affliction among the people.
verses.comment: Jesus’ ministry of teaching, preaching, and healing establishes the paradigm for the Church’s mission: word and sacrament, united to the healing of souls.

verses.text: And His fame spread throughout all Syria, and they brought to Him all the sick, those suffering from various diseases and pains, demoniacs, epileptics, and paralytics—and He healed them.
verses.comment: Christ’s healing power over body and soul manifests His divinity and compassion. The range of healings alludes to the sacramental life later established through His body.

verses.text: And great crowds followed Him from Galilee and the Decapolis, from Jerusalem and Judea, and from beyond the Jordan.
verses.comment: The people from diverse regions drawn to Jesus foreshadow the universal scope of the Church. The theme of gathering all peoples together through Christ’s authority is introduced.
